text:
Uzbekistan Airways to weigh passengers prior to boarding flight Published on : Friday, August 14, 2015
In a recent announcement Uzbekistan Airways announced it will weigh passengers and their carry-on luggage prior to flights to determine how much weight they’ll be adding to the plane.
In a statement, the country’s flag carrier cited the rules of International Air Transport Association which oblige airlines to carry out the regular procedures of pre-flight control passengers weighing with hand baggage to observe requirements for ensuring flight safety.
However, an IATA spokesperson clarified that the organization isn’t aware of any such regulation.
“All airlines have policies in place for load calculations, weight and balance of their aircraft. These policies in turn are subject to the rules and regulations of their national aviation regulator,” said Chris Goater, manager of IATA corporate communications, via email to media.
Uzbekistan Airlines says passengers will be weighed on scales in airport departure zones.
There are formulas in place issued by aviation bodies like the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the European Aviation Safety Agency for airlines to calculate the average weight passengers are adding to a plane. Most commonly, that involves applying an average passenger-mass value.
In 2012, Samoa Air made global headlines by introducing a pay-as-you-weigh fare structure, which is still in place today.
